text: hello this is chef john from food
whooshes comm with how to make pie dough
that's right finally how to make it from
scratch you've seen me use the pre-made
before it's okay but here's how you make
a homemade butter pie dough okay so
we're going to chop up two sticks of
butter unsalted good quality butter
throw it in the freezer that's right
cut in small pieces throw in the freezer
weigh out your flour has to be exact I
have 12 ounces of flour if you don't
have a scale that's about two and a half
cups and also we're going to toss in 1/2
a teaspoon of salt I also have some ice
water and some apple cider vinegar the
amounts are critical get them on the
site if you're not already there alright
throw your flour into the bowl of a food
processor along with your frozen butter
slices pulse on and off just a couple
seconds at a time until you have what
resembles coarse crumbs all right so let
me show you it's going to look something
like that you're gonna be able to see
all those little pieces of butter so you
don't want it too fine but you don't
want any big chunks of butter alright
then we're going to add half the ice
water vinegar mixture pull it on and off
a few times add the other half and then
you're going to pulse on and off until
it just comes together it's going to
look crumbly and it's just going to
start to barely clump so just about
right there do you don't want a solid
dough ball that will be over mixed you
just want to be able to press it and
have a form of dough
all right so pour that crumbly mixture
out on your cutting board I'm using a
silicone baking mat here just for easy
cleanup Pat it into a round shape
something you could divide in half
easily and by the way if you got your
scale out you could do it like the pros
do and weigh each have to get them exact
I'm not big on that form each half into
a disk about 4 or 5 inches wide
refrigerate at least a half hour longer
is even better but at least a half hour
and then you're ready to make pie at
this point you're going to roll out the
bottom half of your pie crust and this
dough if you make it exactly according
to direction is very soft and supple yet
when it bakes up it still has a very
nice flakiness to it apparently the
vinegar the small amount of vinegar
helps keep the gluten from developing so
you don't get a tough crust so this is
nice and flaky and tender and I really
like it okay so once the dough is rolled
out a few inches larger around in your
pie pan I like to roll it up on the
rolling pin easy way to move it around
you sure you've seen that trick before
on TV from those you know uppity pastry
chefs I like to have a lot of overlap
I'm a big crust guy you're going to
throw in your filling in my case the
classic apple pie all right I'm going to
brush the edge with an egg wash that's
just a beaten egg I like to roll my top
crust so I have at least an inch or two
overlapping as you see there actually
have more but I'd like a really thick
outer ring of crust to me that's the
best part of the pie so I don't mind it
a little thinner on top and then have a
lot extra that you'll see I'm just going
to go around and roll up I also like to
crimp the side some people like to use a
fork I just like to pinch every inch or
so to give it that crinkled look by the
way I'm going to link my mom's key lime
pie video under this because she does a
close-up of how to crimp that real easy
trick if you can see it all right brush
the entire surface with your egg wash
anytime you make pie you got to cut some
vents in the top that's also how you can
test with a paring knife later to see if
your apples are tender and then not
shown here I like to give a little
sprinkling of white sugar just a little
bit and that's it bake according to
directions beautiful butter pie dough
pie crust could not be easier if you
have a food processor that is incredibly
simple to make follow this recipe
exactly and you will have pie dough not
pie dough sorry you knew was coming so
give that a try all the ingredients are
on the site the measurements are
critical so go check it out and as
always enjoy
Oh
